Electronic calculators may be used. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 544, 767, 560]]<|/det|> You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 570, 604, 585]]<|/det|> At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 584, 759, 600]]<|/det|> The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 647, 905, 841]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 96, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 863, 91]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will determine the weight of a metre rule using a balancing method. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 576, 122]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions, referring to Fig. 1.1. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[134, 128, 861, 280]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 295, 532, 314]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 327, 144, 345]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 327, 918, 375]]<|/det|> Place the metre rule on the pivot. Place the load P with its centre on the metre rule at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark. Keeping the load P at the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark, adjust the position of the metre rule on the pivot so that the metre rule is as near as possible to being balanced. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 388, 918, 421]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the distance \(a\) from the \(90.0 \text{cm}\) mark to the pivot. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 435, 918, 467]]<|/det|> Measure, and record in the first row of Table 1.1, the distance \(b\) from the pivot to the \(50.0 \text{cm}\) mark. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 481, 920, 514]]<|/det|> Repeat the steps above, placing the centre of the load P at the \(85.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\), \(75.0 \text{cm}\) and \(70.0 \text{cm}\) marks. Record all values of \(a\) and \(b\) in Table 1.1. <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[457, 528, 539, 546]]<|/det|> Table 1.1 <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[361, 555, 636, 712]]<|/det|>
\(a/\text{cm}\)\(b/\text{cm}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|> In this experiment, you will investigate the rate of cooling of water under different conditions. A greater rate of cooling occurs if there is a greater change in the temperature during the same period of time. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 134, 920, 167]]<|/det|> Carry out the following instructions referring to Fig. 3.1. You are provided with a beaker labelled A and a can labelled B. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 177, 737, 405]]<|/det|> <|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[465, 419, 532, 437]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 451, 146, 469]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 450, 615, 469]]<|/det|> Use the thermometer to measure room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[549, 481, 920, 500]]<|/det|>

[1] <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 511, 146, 530]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 511, 920, 545]]<|/det|> Pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into beaker A. Place the lid on the beaker and place the thermometer in the beaker, as shown in Fig. 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 558, 920, 591]]<|/det|> Record in Table 3.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\). Immediately start the stopclock. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 605, 920, 637]]<|/det|> After 30 s, measure the temperature \(\theta\) shown on the thermometer. Record the time \(t = 30\) s and the temperature reading in Table 3.1. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 651, 920, 685]]<|/det|> Continue recording the time and the temperature readings every 30 s until you have six sets of readings. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[892, 683, 920, 701]]<|/det|> [3] <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[275, 714, 356, 732]]<|/det|> Table 3.1 <|ref|>table_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[712, 714, 796, 732]]<|/det|> Table 3.2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[277, 740, 356, 757]]<|/det|> beaker A <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 758, 477, 940]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 599, 920, 664]]<|/det|>
A student in another school carries out the experiment and reports that the rate of cooling of the water in the can is different from the rate of cooling of the water in the beaker. He plans a change to the experiment to find out whether this difference in the rates of cooling is caused by

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 677, 170, 694]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 677, 920, 710]]<|/det|>
the matt black surface of the can being a better radiator of thermal energy than the shiny surface of the beaker

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 724, 170, 741]]<|/det|>
<label>*</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 724, 920, 756]]<|/det|>
the metal of the can being a better conductor of thermal energy than the material of the beaker.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 771, 784, 788]]<|/det|>

<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
A student is investigating the work required to pull a box containing some masses up a sloping wooden board. Fig. 4.1 shows the board and the box.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
Plan an experiment to investigate how the work required to pull the box up the slope depends on the mass of the box and its contents.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 166, 480, 183]]<|/det|>
Work done is calculated using the equation:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 196, 687, 213]]<|/det|>
work done = force \(\times\) distance moved in the direction of the force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 227, 524, 244]]<|/det|>
You are **not** required to carry out this experiment.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 258, 547, 275]]<|/det|>
The following apparatus is available to the students:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 290, 293, 305]]<|/det|>
a wooden board

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 305, 460, 321]]<|/det|>
a box with a length of string attached

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 320, 480, 336]]<|/det|>
a selection of masses that fit in the box

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 336, 260, 351]]<|/det|>
a metre rule

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 352, 339, 367]]<|/det|>
an electronic balance.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 382, 324, 399]]<|/det|>
